chapter.htmlHeader: What is the impact of CVD?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a significant cause of mortality and morbidity, accounting for a quarter of all deaths in the UK. However, annual death rates from CVD have fallen considerably in the UK since the late 1970s. In 1979 the age standardised death rate per 100,000 from CVD was 914 — this has fallen to 251 in 2016.  
  • Mortality from CVD
    • In 2016, around 152,000 people in the UK died from CVD — the second most common cause of death after cancer. Of these:
      • Coronary heart disease (CHD) was the single most common cause resulting in the deaths of 14% of men and 8% of women — a total of about 66,000 deaths.
      • CVD caused 21% of deaths in people under the age of 75 years (premature death) in the UK, about two-thirds were men. 
      • See Table 1 for details of mortality figures from CVD compared with all-cause mortality.
    • CVD death rates vary with age (increase with increasing age), gender (more common in men), time of year (an excess of winter deaths), and also by: 
      • Socioeconomic status — death from CVD is three times higher among people in the most deprived communities compared to those that live in the most affluent.
      • Geographic location — within the UK, the highest rate is in Scotland (315 per 100,000 deaths) and lowest in England. Within England, the highest rate is in Yorkshire and the Humber (277 per 100,000) and lowest in the South East (234 per 100,000). 
  • Morbidity from CVD 
    • Incidence — the British Heart Foundation (BHF) estimates that each year: 
      • There are over 200,000 hospital visits due to myocardial infarction (MI). 
      • Over 100,000 people in the UK have a stroke.
    • Prevalence — the BHF estimates that: 
      • About 2.3 million people in the UK are living with CHD.
      • About 1 million people living in the UK have survived an MI.
      • About 1.3 million people living in the UK have survived a stroke.
  • Financial burden of cardiovascular disease
    • The BHF estimates that CVD costs the UK healthcare system about £9 billion, and costs the UK economy about £19 billion in total.
